user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtPrintx:
```c
void UtPrintx(const void *Memory, uint32 Length)
{
    uint32       i;
    uint32       j;
    const uint8 *Byte_ptr = Memory;
    char         OutputLine[80];
    char *       OutPtr;

    i = 0;
    while (i < Length)
    {
        snprintf(OutputLine, sizeof(OutputLine), "%16lx: ", (unsigned long)&Byte_ptr[i]);
        OutPtr = OutputLine;
        OutPtr += strlen(OutputLine);
        for (j = 0; j < 16 && i < Length; j++, i++)
        {
            sprintf(OutPtr, "%02X  ", Byte_ptr[i]);
            OutPtr += 3;
        }

        UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO, OutputLine);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
snprintf(OutputLine, sizeof(OutputLine), "%16lx: ", (unsigned long)&Byte_ptr[i]);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. Byte_ptr is declared as const uint8 * so &Byte_ptr[i] has type pointer to const-qualified object; taking its address and casting to unsigned long does not change the fact that the pointer points to a const-qualified type. A violation would occur if Byte_ptr were declared as uint8 * (non-const) when it could/should be const.
